questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to the surgical OPD with swelling in the lower abdomen for 5 months. Swelling increases in size on coughing. Patient had been operated on for abdominal hysterectomy 4 years ago. She is also a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for the last 10 years, and is on medications. What would be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has been complaining of lower abdominal swelling for 5 months, which increases on coughing. So, Impulse on coughingis positive, which is the key feature of a hernia. Patient had Operative history of Abdominal hysterectomy 4 years, and has medical history of rheumatoid arthritis on medications since 10 years. So, the patient may be on an immunosuppressant or steroid medications, which can be the causative factor for incisional hernia.
  • Incisional hernias arise through a defect in the musculofascial layers of the abdominal wall in the region of a postoperative scar. Thus, they may appear anywhere on the abdominal surface.
  • Factors predisposing to their development are
    • Patient factors:
      • obesity
      • general poor healing due to malnutrition
      • Immunosuppression or steroid therapy
      • chronic cough
      • cancer
    • Wound factors:
      • poor quality tissues
      • wound infection
    • Surgical factors:
      • inappropriate suture material
      • incorrect suture placement
    • Incisional hernia:
      • Incidence 10-50% after surgery.
      • Causation due to patient, wound and surgeon factors.
      • Wide variation in size.
      • Often multiple defects within the same scar.
      • Obstruction is common but strangulation is rare.
      • Open and laparoscopic repairs possible.

Incorrect options:

Ovarian cyst (Option A) can present with lower abdominal swelling but does not present with impulse on coughing. So, it cannot be the answer.

Abdominal lipoma (Option C) also cannot present with impulse on coughing, so operative and medical history are insignificant for abdominal lipoma. So, it cannot be the answer.

Umbilical hernia (Option D) can present with impulse on coughing, but past medical and operative history are insignificant for umbilical hernia. Umbilical hernia usually occurs in the childhood and presents with the umbilical region swelling and not lower abdominal swelling.

questions.text: All of the following are ventral hernias except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inguinal hernia and Femoral hernia are part of Groin hernias and not ventral hernias.

Ventral hernias:

  • Umbilical-paraumbilical
  • Epigastric (Option A ruled out)
  • Incisional (Option D ruled out)
  • Parastomal
  • Spigelian (Option C ruled out)
  • Lumbar
  • Traumatic

This term refers to hernias of the anterior abdominal wall. Inguinal and femoral hernias are not included even though they are ventral.

Lumbar hernia is included despite being dorsolateral. The European Hernia Society classification (2009) distinguished primary ventral from incisional hernia but did not include parastomal hernia. We have included parastomal hernia and traumatic hernia.

choices.text: Most commonly occurs through the superior lumbar triangle
Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquired
Less commonly occurs through the grynfeltt triangle
Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgeries

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for the lumbar hernias except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lumbar hernia:

  • Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquiredafter an operation on the flank and occurs in the lumbar region of the posterior abdominal wall.
  • Most primary lumbar hernias occur through the inferior lumbar triangle (Petit triangle)bounded below by the crest of the ilium, laterally by the external oblique muscle and medially by latissimus dorsi.
  • Less commonly, the sac comes through the superior lumbar triangle (grynfeltt triangle), which is bounded by the twelfth rib above, medially by sacrospinalis and laterally by the posterior border of the internal oblique muscle.
  • Primary lumbar hernias are rare, but may be mimicked by incisional hernias arising through flank incisions for renal operations, or through incisions for bone grafts harvested from the iliac crest.
  • The natural history is for these hernias to increase in size and surgery is recommended.
  • Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgery. The defects can be difficult to close with sutures and mesh is recommended.

choices.text: Weakness due to ageing and pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause hernia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Muscle damage by blunt trauma or tearing of the abdominal muscles requires exceptional force and is rare.

  • Causes of hernia:
    • Basic design weakness
    • Weakness due to structures entering and leaving the abdomen
    • Developmental failures
    • Genetic weakness of collagen
    • Weakness due to ageing and pregnancy
    • Primary neurological and muscle diseases
    • Excessive intra-abdominal pressure
    • Sharp and blunt trauma
  • Despite the complex design of the abdominal wall, the only natural weaknesses caused by inadequate muscular strength are the Lumbar trianglesand the Posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • An inguinal hernia (Indirect) also occurs through the developmental failure of the processus vaginalis to close.
  • Failure of normal development may lead to weakness of the abdominal wall. Examples areDiaphragmatic, Umbilical and Epigastric hernias.
  • Herniation at the umbilicus has both components, i.e., weakness due to structures passing through the abdominal wall in fetal life and developmental failure of closure.
  • Weakness of abdominal muscles may be the result of Sharp trauma.Most commonly, this results from abdominal surgery but also occurs after stabbing. A surgical scar, even with perfect wound healing, has only 70% of the initial muscle strength. This loss of strength can result in herniation in at least 10% of surgical incisions. Smaller laparoscopic port-site incisions have a hernia rate of 1%.
  • Muscle damage by blunt trauma or tearing of the abdominal muscles requires exceptional force and is rare.
  • Primary muscle pathology and neurological conditions can lead to muscle weakness and occasionally present to the surgeon as a 'hernia'.

questions.text: Which hormonal component is responsible for the closure of processus vaginalis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An Inguinal hernia (Indirect) also occurs through the developmental failure of the processus vaginalis to close. As the testis descends, it pulls a tube of peritoneum along with it. This tube should naturally fibrose and become obliterated but often it fails to fibrose and allows a hernia to form.
  • Recent studies have shown that Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and Hepatocyte growth factorinfluence the closure of the processus, raising the possibility of a hormonal cause of hernia development.
  • Closure normally occurs at 3-12 months post-natally

Incorrect options:

Testosterone (Option A): Drives testicular descent but no role in closure of processus vaginalis.

Estrogen (Option C): No direct role in processus vaginalis closure.

Glucagon (Option D): Unrelated to inguinal development.

questions.text: For a hernia to occur, weakness can be in any of the following layers except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There is no defect in the peritoneum in the case of a hernia. The peritoneum itself is a part of hernia which forms the sac.
  • An abdominal wall hernia has two essential components: Defect in the walland Content.
  • The weakness in the wall is usually the narrowest part of the hernia which expands into the subcutaneous fat outside the muscle.

Incorrect options:

Muscle (Option A): weakness in the muscle layer can lead to incisional hernia.

Bony component (Option B): weakness in the bony component can lead to femoral hernia.

Fascia (Option D): weakness in the fascia can lead to epigastric hernia.

questions.text: In a case of hernia, the risk of strangulation is maximum in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In case of hernia, the defect varies in size and may be very small or indeed very large. The nature of the defect is important to understanding the risk of hernia complications.
  • A small defect with rigid wallstraps the content and prevents it from freely moving in and out of the defect, increasing the risk of complications.
  • When tissue is trapped inside a hernia it is in a confined space. The narrow neck acts as a constriction ringimpeding venous return and increasing pressure within the hernia. Resulting tension leads to pain and tenderness. If the hernia contains bowel, then it may become 'obstructed', partially or totally. If the pressure rises sufficiently, arterial blood is not able to enter the hernia and the contents become ischaemic and may infarct. The hernia is then said to have 'strangulated'.
  • The wall of the bowel perforates, releasing infected, toxic bowel content into the tissues and ultimately back into the peritoneal cavity.
  • The risk of strangulation is highest in hernias that have a small neck of rigid tissue, leading first to irreducibilityand on to strangulation. The term 'incarcerated' is not clearly defined and used to imply a hernia that is irreducible and developing towards strangulation.

I - b, II - c, III - d, IV - a
I - c, II - d, III - a, IV - b
I - d, II - a, III - b, IV - c

questions.text: Match the following for the type of hernia by its complexity:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Types of hernia by complexity:

  • Occult - not detectable clinically; may cause severe pain.
  • Reducible - a swelling that appears and disappears.
  • Irreducible - a swelling that cannot be replaced in the abdomen, high risk of complications.
  • Strangulated - painful swelling with vascular compromise, requires urgent surgery.
  • Infarcted - when contents of the hernia have become gangrenous, high mortality.

choices.text: Reduction of the hernia content into the abdominal cavity with removal of any non-viable tissue and bowel repair if necessary
Reapproximation of the walls of the neck of the hernia if possible
Permanent reinforcement of the abdominal wall defect with sutures or mesh

questions.text: All of the following are basic principles for surgical repair of hernia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

All surgical repairs follow the same basic principles:

  1. Permanent reinforcement of the abdominal wall defect with sutures or mesh (Option D ruled out).
  2. Reapproximation of the walls of the neck of the hernia if possible (Option C ruled out).
  3. Excision and closure of a peritoneal sac if present or replacing it deep to the muscles;
  4. Reduction of the hernia content into the abdominal cavity with removal of any non-viable tissue and bowel repair if necessary(Option A ruled out).

questions.text: What should be the minimum length of mesh overlap around all margins of the defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A well-placed mesh should have good overlap around all margins of the defect, at least 2 cm but up to 5 cm if possible.

choices.text: Fibrous tissue in growth between the strands
Mesh gets plugged with the tissue
Neovascular ingrowth and new collagen deposition

questions.text: Synthetic Hernia mesh fixes with the tissue by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Net meshesare woven or knitted. Flat sheets are not porous but can be perforated with multiple holes.
  • Meshes for hernia repair are generally non-absorbable and designed to provoke tissue ingrowth that leads to the formation of a tissue barrier.
  • Net meshes allowfibrous tissue growth between the strands and becoming adherent and integrated into host tissues within a few months.
  • The fibrous tissue thus formed gradually contracts and leads to'Mesh Contracture'.
  • 'Sheet' meshes do not allow host tissue in growth but become encapsulated by fibrous tissue. They always require strong, non-absorbable fixation to prevent mesh migration.

questions.text: Synthetic meshes can be made from all of the following materials except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most meshes used today are synthetic polymers of Polypropylene, Polyesteror Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). They are non-absorbable and provoke little tissue reaction.
  • Polypropylene makes a strong monofilament mesh. It does not have any antibacterial properties but its hydrophobicnature and monofilament microstructure impede bacterial in-growth.
  • Polyester is a braided filament This structure may allow infection to take hold, aided by its hydrophilicproperty. However, this property also allows rapid vascular and cellular infiltration within the fibrils, aiding host immune responses to infection and providing a stronger host-tissue interface.
  • PTFE meshes are flat sheetsand as a result do not allow any tissue in-growth. They are used as a non-adhesive barrier between tissue layers.

questions.text: Hernia mesh usually shrinks by how much percentage?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Synthetic meshes are very strong and early meshes were much stronger than a human abdominal wall, so they are considered as 'over-engineered'. All meshes provoke a fibrous reaction.
  • Denser or heavyweight meshes provoke a greater reaction, leading to collagen contraction and stiffening.
  • The term 'mesh shrinkage'is often used to describe a progressive decrease in size of a mesh over time. It is due to natural contraction of fibrous tissue embedded in the mesh, reducing the area of mesh itself. This can lead to tissue tension and pain, a common complication of mesh repair. It can also lead to hernia recurrence if the mesh no longer covers the defect.
  • Meshes can shrink by up to 50%and, in occasional cases, even more.
  • Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces between them, 'lightweight, large-pore meshes', are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less shrinkage, more flexibility and improved comfort.

questions.text: What should be the pore size of light weight meshes?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The terms 'light', 'medium' and 'heavy' are not precisely defined but meshes > 1.0 mm pore size are generally referred to as lightweight meshes.
  • Lightweight meshes are preferred as they promote collagen ingrowth, making it both strong and elastic, and is more effectively integrated to the tissue.
  • Example: Lightweight Polypropylene mesh

questions.text: What should be the weight of heavy weight meshes?
questions.solution:
The terms 'light', 'medium' and 'heavy' are not precisely defined but meshes <40 g/m2 are generally referred to as light and meshes >80 g/m2 as heavy.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 64, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1064

questions.text: Biological Hernia mesh fixes with the tissue by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There are 'biological meshes'that are sheets of sterilised, decellularised, non-immunogenic connective tissue. They derive from human or animal dermis, bovine pericardium or porcine intestinal submucosa.
  • They provide a 'scaffold'to encourage neovascular in-growth and new collagen deposition. Host enzymes eventually break down the biological implant, which is replaced and remodelled with 'normal' host fibrous tissue.
  • They are derived from Human or Animal dermis, Bovine pericardium or Porcine intestinal submucosa.
  • The rates of enzymatic degradation and collagen deposition vary between products and also depend on the local environment of the mesh.
  • In the presence of infection, some biological meshes rapidly break down and weaken before remodelling can occur. Others remain strong, their labyrinthine microstructure allowing vascular in-growth to aid infection resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polypropylenemeshes are synthetic, non-absorbable.
  • There are also synthetic absorbable meshes, such as those made from polyglycolic acid fibre.
  • They are used in temporary abdominal wall closure and to buttress sutured repairs. They have no current role in hernia repair because they absorb and induce minimal collagen deposition.
  • In recent years a number of synthetic, slowly absorbable meshes have been developed.
  • These are designed to be gradually degraded by the body and replaced with strong native collagenous fibrosis in order to create a lasting repair.
  • The long-term outcomes of repairs using these meshes are as yet unknown.

questions.text: Match the following for the placement of the mesh in different layers:.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The strength of a mesh repair depends on host-tissue in-growth. Meshes should be placed on a firm, well vascularised tissue bed with generous overlap of the defect.

The mesh can be placed:

  • Just outside the muscle in the subcutaneous space (onlay)
  • Within the defect (inlay)- only applies to mesh plugs in small defects
  • Between fascial layers in the abdominal wall (intraparietal)
  • Immediately extraperitoneally, against muscle or fascia (also sublay)
  • Intraperitoneally.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is the defect in which layer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As the testis descends from the abdominal cavity to the scrotum in males it first passes through a defect called the deep inguinal ring in the transversalis fascia, just deep to the abdominal muscles.
  • This ring lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle, or 5 cm above the midpoint of anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle,approximately 2-3 cm above the femoral artery pulse in the groin.
  • The inferior epigastric vessels lie just medial to the deep inguinal ring, passing from the iliac vessels to rectus abdominis.
  • Muscle fibres of the innermost two layers of the lateral abdominal wall, the transversus muscle and the internal oblique muscle, arch over the deep inguinal ring from lateral to medial before descending to become attached to the pubic tubercle.
  • These two muscles fuse and become tendinous, hence this arch is referred to as the conjoint tendon. Below this arch there is no muscle but only transversalis fascia and external oblique aponeurosis, resulting in weakness.

questions.text: Superficial inguinal ring is the defect in which layer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The testis proceeds medially and downwards along the inguinal canal. Anterior to the canal is the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle, the fibres of which run downwards and medially.
  • The testis finally emerges through a V-shaped defect in the aponeurosis, thesuperficial inguinal ring, and descends into the scrotum.
  • The inguinal canal is roofed by the conjoint tendon, its posterior wall is transversalis fascia, an anterior wall is the external oblique aponeurosis and a floor, which is also the external oblique, that rolls inwards at its lower margin and thickens to become the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • The inguinal canal in males contains the testicular artery, veins, lymphatics and the vas deferens. In females, the round ligamentdescends through the canal to end in the vulva.
  • Three important nerves, theilioinguinal, the iliohypogastric and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, also pass through the canal.

questions.text: Lateral border of the Hasselbach's triangle is formed by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hasselbach's (Hesselbach's) Triangle

This is an anatomical area in the anterior abdominal wall of clinical importance, as it is a common site for direct inguinal hernias.

Boundaries of Hesselbach's Triangle:

  1. Medial Border:Lateral margin of the rectus abdominis muscle.
  2. Lateral Border:Inferior epigastric vessels.
  3. Inferior Border:Inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament).

Clinical Significance:

The primary clinical importance of Hesselbach's Triangle lies in its relationship to hernias.

The inferior epigastric vessels serve as the critical anatomical reference point for differentiating between the two main types of inguinal hernias:

  • Direct Inguinal Hernia:
    • Location:Herniates within the Hesselbach's triangle.
    • Pathway:The hernia sac protrudes directly forward through a weakness or defect in the transversalis fascia of the abdominal wall (the floor of the inguinal canal). It is acquired, often due to heavy lifting or aging.
    • Relation to Vessels:The hernia sac is located medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia:
    • Location:Herniates outside and lateral to the Hesselbach's triangle.
    • Pathway:The hernia sac follows the path of the spermatic cord (in males) or round ligament (in females) through the deep inguinal ring.
    • Relation to Vessels:The hernia sac is located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: According to the European hernia society classification, a primary indirect inguinal hernia of 3cm defect size would be classified as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of:

  • Primary or recurrent (P or R);
  • Lateral, medial or femoral (L, M or F); lateral denotes for indirect hernia and medial denotes for direct hernia
  • Defect size in fingerbreadths assumed to be 1.5 cm.

A primary, indirect, inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be PL2.

questions.text: All of the following is true for Gilmore's hernia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sportsmen's groin, also called sports hernia and Gilmore groin, is one of the most frequent sports injuries in athletes and may place an athletic career at risk.
  • It presents with acute or chronic groin pain exacerbated with physical activity.
  • So far, there is little consensus regarding pathogenesis, diagnostic criteria, or treatment. There have been various attempts to explain the cause of the groin pain.
  • The assumption is that a circumscribed weakness in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, which leads to a localized bulge, induces a compression of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, considered responsible for the symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form the walls of the femoral hernia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The femoral canal, through which a femoral hernia passes, has specific anatomical boundaries. Option A is incorrect because the femoral vein forms the lateral wall of the femoral canal, not the femoral artery.

Anatomy of the Femoral Canal & Hernia:

  • The femoral canalis the medialmost compartment of the femoral sheath, a funnel-shaped fascial tube that surrounds the proximal part of the femoral vessels as they pass deep to the inguinal ligament.
  • The femoral canal is bounded by:
  • Anteriorly:Inguinal ligament
  • Posteriorly:Pectineal ligament
  • Medially:Lacunar ligament
  • Laterally:Femoral vein
  • A femoral hernia occurs when abdominal contents (often preperitoneal fat or a loop of intestine) protrude through the femoral ringinto the femoral canal. It presents as a mass or bulge below the inguinal ligament, in the upper thigh.

Key Characteristics:

  • More common in womendue to a wider pelvis, which creates a larger femoral ring.
  • The hernia sac passes inferior and lateralto the pubic tubercle. This is a key differentiator from an inguinal hernia, which passes superior and medial to the pubic tubercle.
  • The path of a femoral hernia is rigid and narrow, making it prone to complications.

Clinical Significance of Femoral Hernia:

1. High Risk of Strangulation and Obstruction

  • The femoral ring is a rigid, non-distensible opening.
  • Because of this narrow opening, femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulationamong all abdominal wall hernias (up to 40% present as an emergency).
  • Strangulationoccurs when the blood supply to the herniated tissue (e.g., intestine) is cut off by the tight neck of the hernia sac. This leads to bowel ischemia, necrosis (tissue death), and perforation.
  • Obstructionoccurs when the herniated bowel loop blocks the passage of intestinal contents.

2. Diagnosis

  • They are often small and may not be noticeable to the patient until they become incarcerated (cannot be pushed back in) or strangulated.
  • The bulge can be difficult to palpate, especially in obese patients.
  • It can be misdiagnosed as an inguinal hernia, lymph node, or saphena varix (a dilation of the saphenous vein).

3. The "Crural Triangle" and Richter's Hernia

  • The space between the lacunar ligament (medially) and the femoral vein (laterally) is known as the crural triangle. This is the potential site of herniation.
  • A Richter's Herniais a dangerous variant where only one part of the circumference of the bowel wall becomes trapped and strangulated in the hernia sac. This can lead to bowel perforation without the classic signs of intestinal obstruction, making diagnosis even more difficult.

4. Management

  • Due to the high risk of strangulation, surgical repair (herniorrhaphy/hernioplasty) is always recommendedonce a femoral hernia is diagnosed, even if it is asymptomatic.
  • Emergency surgery is required for cases presenting with incarceration, obstruction, or strangulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true for femoral hernia?
questions.solution:
• The iliac artery and vein pass below the inguinal ligament to become the femoral vessels in the leg. The vein lies medially and the artery just lateral to the artery with the femoral nerve lateral to the artery. They are enclosed in a fibrous sheath. Just medial to the vein is a small space containing fat and some lymphatic tissue (node of Cloquet). It is this space which is exploited by a femoral hernia.
  • The walls of a femoral hernia are the femoral vein laterally, the inguinal ligament anteriorly, the pelvic bone covered by the iliopectineal ligament (Astley Cooper's) posteriorly and the lacunar ligament (Gimbernat's) medially. This is a strong curved ligament with a sharp unyielding edge which impedes reduction of a femoral hernia.
  • The female pelvis has a different shape to the male, increasing the size of the femoral canal and the risk of hernia. In old age, the femoral defect increases and femoral hernia is commonly seen in low-weight, elderly women. There is a substantial risk of developing a femoral hernia after a sutured inguinal hernia repair (Denmark Hernia Registry).
  • Less common than inguinal hernia
  • It is more common in women than in men
  • Easily missed on examination
  • Of cases 50% present as an emergency with very high risk of strangulation

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 64, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1072

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of femoral hernia repair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of Femroal hernias, there are three open approaches and appropriate cases can be managed laparoscopically.

  • Low approach (lockwood):
    • This is the simplest operation for a femoral hernia but suitable only when there is no risk of bowel resection. It can easily be performed under local anaesthesia.
  • The inguinal approach (lotheissen):
    • In this, the initial incision is identical to that of Bassini's or Lichtenstein's operation into the inguinal canal.
  • High approach (McEvedy):
    • This more complex operation is ideal in the emergency situation where the risk of bowel strangulation is high. It requires regional or general anaesthesia.
  • Laparoscopic approach:
    • Both the TEP and TAPP approaches can be used for a femoral hernia and a standard mesh inserted.
    • This is ideal for reducible femoral hernias presenting electively, but not for emergency cases or irreducible hernia.
    • Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal repair, done for inguinal hernias

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true for umbilical hernia in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Umbilical hernia in children:

  • This common condition occurs in up to 10% of infants, with a higher incidence in premature babies.
  • The hernia appears within a few weeks of birth and is often symptomless, but increases in size on crying and assumes a classic conical shape.
  • Sexes are equally affected but the incidence in black infants is up to eight times higher than in white.
  • Obstruction and/ or strangulation is extremely uncommon below the age of 3 years.

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment is indicated under the age of 2 years when the hernia is symptomless. Parental reassurance is all that is necessary. Of hernias 95% will resolve spontaneously.
  • If the hernia persists beyond the age of 2 yearsit is unlikely to resolve and surgical repair is indicated.

Surgery:

  • A small curved incision is made immediately below the umbilicus.
  • The neck of the sac is defined, opened and any contents are returned to the peritoneal cavity. The sac is closed and redundant sac excised.
  • The defect in the linea alba is closed with interrupted sutures.

questions.text: Mayo's repair for umbilical hernia is usually performed for how much centimetre radius of defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mayo's repair for umbilical hernia repair is done for defect size of 2 cm diameter.So, in radius it is 1 cm of defect size.
  • Very small defects less than 1 cm in size may be closed with a simple figure-of-eight suture, or repaired by a darn techniquewhere a non-absorbable, monofilament suture is crisscrossed across the defect and anchored firmly to the fascia all around.
  • Defects up to 2 cm in diameter may be sutured primarily with minimal tension, although, the larger the defect, the more tension and the more likely it is that mesh reinforcement will be beneficial.
  • The classic repair was described by Mayo. A transverse incision is made and the hernia sac dissected, opened and its content reduced. Any non-viable tissue is removed, sometimes involving bowel resection. The peritoneum is closed. The tissue is double breasted. Non-absorbable sutures are used. There is often a large subcutaneous space. A suction drain is placed. The skin is closed but stretched or redundant skin may need to be excised (apronectomy) to achieve a better cosmetic result.
  • For defects larger than 2 cm in diameter, mesh repair is recommended.
  • The Mayo repair remains popular for defects up to 2 cm, but the larger the defect the more tissue tension. Current evidence advises the use of mesh even in small defects, and certainly for all defects larger than 2 cm, owing to the high likelihood of recurrence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the surgical opd with soft midline swelling in the upper abdomen for 6 months. Cough impulse is present over the swelling and there is no operative past history. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A middle-aged male patient with soft midline swelling with cough impulse present is most probablyepigastric hernia.
  • These hernias arise through the midline raphe (linea alba) anywhere between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus, usually midway.
  • When close to the umbilicus they are called supraumbilical hernias. Epigastric hernias begin with a transverse split in the midline rapheso, in contrast to umbilical hernias, the defect is elliptical.
  • It has been hypothesised that the defect occurs at the site where small blood vessels pierce the linea alba or, more likely, that it arises at weaknesses due to abnormal decussation of aponeurotic fibres related to heavy physical activity.

Clinical features:

  • The patients are often fit, healthy men aged between 25 and 40 years.
  • These hernias can be very painfuleven when the swelling is the size of a pea, due to the fatty contents becoming nipped sufficiently to produce partial strangulation.

Treatment:

  • Very small epigastric hernias have been known to disappear spontaneously, probably due to infarction of the fat.
  • Small to moderate-sized hernias without a peritoneal sac are not inherently dangerous and surgery should be offered only if the hernia is sufficiently symptomatic.

Surgery:

  • may be done by open or laparoscopic surgery.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Incisional hernia (Option A): it cannot be incisional hernia because there is no past history of any surgical procedure done.

Lipoma (Option B): it cannot be lipoma because cough impulse is present, which is not relevant to lipoma

Umbilical hernia (Option D): it cannot be umbilical hernia because the swelling is in the upper abdomen and not at the umbilical region.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true for obturator hernia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Obturator hernia:

  • Obturator hernia, which passes through the obturator canal, occurs six times more frequently in women than in men. Most patients are aged >60 years.
  • The swelling is liable to be overlooked because it is covered by pectineus. It seldom causes a definite swelling in Scarpa's triangle, but, if the limb is flexed, abducted and rotated outwards, the hernia sometimes becomes apparent.
  • The leg is usually kept in a semiflexed position and movement increases the pain.
  • In more than 50% of cases of strangulated obturator hernia, pain is referred along the obturator nerve by its geniculate branch to the knee.
  • On vaginal or rectal examination, the hernia can sometimes be felt as a tender swelling in the region of the obturator foramen.
  • These hernias have often undergone strangulation, frequently of the Richter type, by the time of presentation.

questions.text: Synergistic gangrene occurs due to synergistic action of which two organisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Synergistic gangrene:

  • This rare condition is due to the synergistic action of non-haemolytic streptococci and staphylococcicausing rapid tissue necrosis and overwhelming systemic infection.
  • It requires immediate administration of high-dose, broad-spectrum, powerful antibiotics in combination with early debridement of any non-viable tissue. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been advocated.
  • Other forms of severe abdominal wall infections occur, generally known as necrotising fasciitis (e.g., Fournier's gangrene). All of these conditions have a high associated morbidity and mortality.
  • They occur in debilitated and immunocompromised patientsbut can occasionally occur in healthy patients. Rapid diagnosis and aggressive surgical debridement treatment are the key to success.

questions.text: Label the diagram correctly for the position of the mesh placement in hernia surgery
questions.solution:
• Onlay - placement of the mesh over the anterior rectus sheath
  • Sublay - placement of the mesh below the rectus muscle and over the posterior rectus sheath
  • Pre-peritoneal - placement of the mesh below the posterior rectus sheath and above the peritoneum
  • Intraperitoneal - placement of the mesh intraabdominally below the peritoneum

The strength of a mesh repair depends on host-tissue in-growth. Meshes should be placed on a firm, well vascularised tissue bed with generous overlap of the defect.

  • The mesh can be placed:
  • just outside the muscle in the subcutaneous space (onlay);
  • within the defect (inlay) - only applies to mesh plugs in small defects;
  • between fascial layers in the abdominal wall (intraparietal or sublay);
  • immediately extraperitoneally, against muscle or fascia (also sublay);
  • intraperitoneally.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 64, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1064

questions.text: Spigelian fascia is the aponeurosis of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spigelian hernia

  • These hernias affect men and women equally and can occur at any age, but are most common in elderly people.
  • They arise through a defect in the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. Often these hernias advance through the internal oblique as well and spread out deep to the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • The spigelian fascia extends between the transversus muscle and the lateral border of the rectus sheath from the costal margin to the groin, where it blends into the conjoint tendon.
  • Most Spigelian hernias appear below the level of the umbilicus near the edge of the rectus sheath, but they can be found anywhere along the spigelian line.

Clinical features

  • Young patients usually present with intermittent pain, due to pinching of the fat, similar to an epigastric hernia.
  • A lump may or may not be palpable because the fatty hernia is small and the overlying external oblique is intact. Older patients may have symptoms of intermittent obstruction.

Treatment

  • Surgery is recommended because the narrow and fibrous neck predisposes to strangulation. Surgery can be open or laparoscopic.
  • Laparoscopy is useful if no sac is palpable, repair can be performed using either the intraperitoneal onlay of mesh (IPOM) or TAPP technique.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient came to surgical opd presenting with reducible swelling just above the umbilicus for 5 months. Patient is suffering from copd and liver cirrhosis. On examination cough impulse is present over the swelling and one finger defect is palpable. On ultrasound scan the defect size is 1.5 cm diameter. Which surgical procedure should be advisable in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to the history given above, patient is suffering from paraumbilical hernia.
  • As the defect size is less than 2cm diameter, mayo's repair is best advisable considering the medical history of the patient.
  • Mayo's repair is also known as double breasting technique.

Umbilical hernia in adults:

  • Conditions that cause stretching and thinning of the midline raphe (linea alba), such as pregnancy, obesityand liver disease with cirrhosis, predispose to reopening of the umbilical defect.
  • In adults, the defect in the median raphe is immediately adjacent to (most often above) the true umbilicus. The term 'paraumbilical hernia'is commonly used. The defect is rounded with a well-defined fibrous margin.

Clinical features:

  • The bulge is typically slightly to one side of the umbilical depression, creating a crescent-shaped appearance to the umbilicus.
  • Women are affected more than men. Most patients complain of pain due to tissue tension or symptoms of intermittent bowel obstruction. In large hernias, the overlying skin may become thinned, stretched and develop dermatitis.

Treatment:

  • As a result of the high risk of strangulation, surgery should be advised in cases where the hernia contains bowel.
  • Surgery may be performed open or laparoscopically.

Open umbilical hernia repair:

  • Very small defects less than 1 cm in size may be closed with a simple figure-of-eight suture, or repaired by a darn technique where a non-absorbable, monofilament suture is crisscrossed across the defect and anchored firmly to the fascia all around.
  • Defects up to 2 cm in diameter may be sutured primarily with minimal tension, although, the larger the defect, the more tension and the more likely it is that mesh reinforcement will be beneficial.
  • The classic repair was described by For defects larger than 2 cm in diameter, mesh repair is recommended.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hernioplasty surgery (Option A): In hernioplasty surgery, hernia mesh is placed. But as the defect size is less than 2 cm diameter hernioplasty surgery is not required.

Laparoscopic IPOM surgery (Option C): Considering the medical condition of the patient and age of the patient, as patient is suffering from COPD and liver cirrhosis, the risk of general anaesthesia increases. And mayo's repair can be performed under spinal anaesthesia in favourable conditions.

Simple primary closure of the defect (Option D): considering the age of the patient and medical condition of COPD, simple primary closure of the defect can lead to recurrence because of possibility of weakness of the abdominal muscle tone and chronic cough.

questions.text: All of the following help in reducing the risk of incisional hernia formation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reducing the risk of incisional hernia

  • The incidence of incisional hernia may be reduced by improving the patient's general condition preoperatively where possible, e.g., weight loss for obesity or improving nutritional state for malnutrition.
  • Closing the fascial layers with non-absorbable, or very slowly absorbable, sutures of adequate gauge is important.
  • Traditional teaching was that sutures should be 1 cm deep and 1 cm apart. Recent work has shown that lower incisional hernia rates and reduced infection rates are gained when smaller and closer bites are used with a 2/0 suture rather than traditional heavier materials.
  • There is no evidence that interrupted sutures are better or worse than continuous. However, if continuous suturing is used, the tissue bites must not be too near the fascial edge or pulled too tight because they may cut out.
  • It has also been confirmed that the optimal ratio of suture length to wound length is 4:1 (Jenkins' rule). If less length than this is used, the suture bites are too far apart or too tight and the converse applies if more length than this is used.
  • Drains should be brought out through separate incisions and not through the wound itself because this leads to hernia formation.
  • Recent reports have suggested that placement of a prophylactic mesh in patients at high risk of hernia formation will substantially reduce that risk.

questions.text: All of the following are open incisional hernia repair techniques except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Desarda's repair is the open hernia repair used in inguinal herniasurgery not for incisional hernia.

Treatment of incisional hernia:

  • Asymptomatic incisional hernias may not require treatment at all. The wearing of an abdominal binder or belt may prevent the hernia from increasing in size.

Principles of surgery:

  • For most incisional hernias, surgery is relatively straightforward and both openand laparoscopic options are available.
  • The repair should cover the whole length of the previous incision.
  • Approximation of the musculofascial layers should be done with minimal tension and prosthetic mesh should be used to reduce the risk of recurrence.

Open repair:

  • Simple suture techniques without the use of prosthetic mesh for reinforcement, even with layered closure such as in Mayo, 'keel' or da Silvarepairs, are not recommended today because of the high risk of recurrence. However, they may be the only option in the presence of gross contamination such as peritonitis. The previous incision is opened along its full length to reveal any clinically unsuspected defects.
  • Mesh can be placed in one of several planes as for umbilical hernia repair. The simplest approach is an onlaymesh but increasingly the retromuscular sublay repair is preferred by expert surgeons.
  • Very large incisional hernias often require careful thought before treatment begins. Ramirez's component separation technique, which incorporates relaxing incisions in the external oblique aponeurosis and/or the posterior sheath, is very useful. It may then be reinforced with a mesh.
  • Patients with poor quality or redundant skin may benefit from a wedge excision of skin and fat (lipectomy) to improve the abdominal contour postoperatively.
